HDG.LP.content: Geist (ghost or spirit), via Trakl, possibility of both gentleness and destructiveness (Zerstörerischen) > Das Sanfte [gentleness] schlägt jenes Außer-sich des Entflammenden keineswegs nieder, sondern hält es in der Ruhe des Freundlichen versammelt [holds ek-stasis in peace of friendship] > Das Zerstörerische [destructiveness] kommt aus dem Zügellosen, das sich im eigenen Aufruhr verzehrt und so das Bösartige betreibt [consumes itself, unbridled evil] > evil is ghostly, the revolt (Aufruhr) of a terror blazing away in blindness, the ungathered, fragmented, unholy—threatens to turn gentleness to ash (des Sanften zu versengen droht) [cf. Derrida on absolute ash]

HDG.LP.content: the way apartness flames, it is spirit & thus gathering power, Das Versammelnde der Abgeschiedenheit, saves the unborn beyond the used-up for a coming rebirth of mankind, gathering power, spirit of gentleness, stills spirit of evil

HDG.LP.content: in Einfalt of childhood is hidden (verbirgt) the geschwisterliche Zwiefalt des Menschengeschlechtes [the brotherly/sisterly twofoldness of mankind] > in apartness, evil neither destroyed/denied nor set free/affirmed: evil is transformed (to endure this transformation, soul must be great)

HDG.EC.content: because devastation is deeper, comes from farther away, our thoughts return to it again and again > the devastation of earth, the annihilation (Vernichtung) of human essence: evil itself (das Böse selbst) > evil not as the morally bad, the reprehensible, but as malice (Bösartige)

HDG.EC.content: malice is insurgency (Aufrührerische), das im Grimmigen beruht (rests in furiousness) > essence of evil is rage (Ingrimm) of insurgency (furiousness conceals this rage, in a certain sense) > perhaps the will itself is what is evil > yes, perhaps

HDG.EC.content: referring to evil I see better how we can encounter devastation, that we cannot encounter devastation > must think devastation more rigorously > since devastation is not moral badness (Schlechtigkeit), moral indignation (moralische Entrüstung), even if it makes general public (Weltöffentlichkeit) its mouthpiece, can’t do anything against devastation > moral superiority (Überlegenheit) in no position to grasp, much less abolish (aufzuheben)/mitigate evil

HDG.EC.content: could be that morality, w/ its visions of world order, is a monstrous offspring (Ausgeburt) of evil, & the much-appealed-to (vielberufene) Weltöffentlichkeit (word’s general public) remains in essence a construct (Gebild) and product (Erzeugnis) of devastation

HDG.EC.content: Nietzsche interpreted morality, the Platonic-Christian ethical doctrine, & its later secularized forms (rational Ethics of Enlightenment/socialism), as appearances (Erscheinungen) of will to power > Nietzsche didn’t realize that a will to power “beyond good & evil,” as realm of pure will to power, remains only counter-world (Gegenwelt) to Platonism > Nietzsche’s doctrine of “discipline and breeding (Zucht und Züchtung)” is extreme affirmation of morality > if will is evil, will to power is least of all beyond evil

HDG.EC.content: doesn’t this thought that Being is malicious (bösartig) in the Ground of its essence (im Grunde seines Wesens) place an awful demand (arge Zumutung) on human thinking? > even more when one should not regard the idea that evil dwells in essence of Being as pessimistic > that thinking should be easy is a thought from spirit of devastation [spirit of revenge?]
